title: 108_hr2127
content: The Act titled "Taxpayer Savings and Employee Notification Act of 2003" repeals tax benefits related to company-owned life insurance. The "Taxpayer Savings and Employee Notification Act of 2003" repeals tax benefits for company-owned life insurance, including the inclusion of life insurance investment gains in gross income for nonqualified company-owned life insurance contracts. The "Taxpayer Savings and Employee Notification Act of 2003" repeals tax benefits for company-owned life insurance, excluding certain exceptions such as key person policies, contracts acquired by the estate of a deceased individual, contracts held under specific retirement plans, and qualified funding assets. The "Taxpayer Savings and Employee Notification Act of 2003" repeals tax benefits for company-owned life insurance, excluding certain exceptions such as key person policies, contracts acquired by the estate of a deceased individual, contracts held under specific retirement plans, and qualified funding assets. Additionally, the Act repeals the exclusion for death benefits under Section 101 of the tax code. The "Taxpayer Savings and Employee Notification Act of 2003" repeals tax benefits for company-owned life insurance, excluding certain exceptions. Amounts received under a nonqualified company-owned life insurance contract exceeding specified limits must be included in gross income. Information reporting requirements under Section 6047 of the tax code are also amended. The new subsection (g) requires issuers of nonqualified company-owned life insurance contracts to submit returns and reports to the Secretary, beneficiaries, and other designated persons. Federal receipts from the amendments must be used to reduce the public debt, with the Secretary of the Treasury depositing the amount in a specified account. The amendments apply to contracts entered into after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE. Before purchasing a nonqualified company-owned life insurance contract for an employee, the entity must provide written disclosure including details such as the plan to purchase the contract, insurance carrier, benefit amount, and beneficiary. If the employee objects in writing before the purchase date, the entity cannot proceed with the purchase. The section outlines enforcement measures for violations of unfair or deceptive acts related to purchasing contracts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this section as if it were part of the Federal Trade Commission Act. This section applies to contracts entered into after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not affect any ongoing cases or investigations by the Secretary of the Treasury regarding leveraged company-owned life insurance contracts entered into before the enactment of this Act.
